results.title: Rural industries
results.creator_credit: John Leake, Peter Johnson, Film Australia and Motion Picture Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia in the 80’s”.
Australia’s modern techniques of cultivation and harvesting are demonstrated to show how this country is a major supplier of grain to the world. The film also shows how the cattle and livestock industry supply food to most parts of the globe.

results.title: Australia Council archival film series: writers III
results.title_for_label: Australia Council archival film series: writers III
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Elizabeth Jolley
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers III”.
One of Australia’s most popular and acclaimed novelists, Elizabeth Jolley recalls her childhood and the influence of her Quaker upbringing in the industrial north of England. Jolley emigrated to Western Australia with her husband and three children and worked as a cleaner and travelling saleswoman to support her writing. Despite twenty years of rejection slips her first book of short fiction, “Five Acre Virgin and Other Stories” was eventually published in 1976. Another five books were released in the following six years and her radio plays were produced by both the ABC and the BBC World Service. Jolley asserts the importance of imagination over experience in her creative life and her belief in the value of regional fiction. Research and interview: James Murdoch.

group.title: Australia Council archival film series: writers III

results.title: Dorothy Hewett
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers III”.
Dorothy Hewett reflects on her life as a playwright, poet, author and teacher. Hewett grew up in Western Australia and has been a writer all her life. A political, social and sexual rebel, she has created work which has often been controversial for its frankness and for the power of her female central characters. In this 1991 interview, Hewett discusses the professional and personal relationships that have enriched her life and inspired her writing. She also speaks about ageing and her struggle to overcome the loss of physical power. Research and interview: James Murdoch.

results.title: Australia Council archival film series: writers I
results.title_for_label: Australia Council archival film series: writers I

results.title: Hal Porter
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
A witty, biting commentary about life and an author’s place in it. Hal Porter reminisces about teaching, acting, producing for the theatre, and his life in Melbourne, Bairnsdale and Japan.

results.title: Christina Stead
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
In the only filmed interview with one of Australia’s most popular and respected novelists, Christina Stead is both challenging and revealing.

group.title: Australia Council archival film series: writers I

results.title: Marjorie Barnard
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
Historical novelist, Marjorie Barnard recalls priceless memories of fellow writers who “peopled her world”, including Xavier Herbert, Vance and Nettie Palmer and Frank Dalby Davison.

group.title: Australia Council archival film series: writers I

results.title: A.D. Hope
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
A D Hope talks in this entertaining interview of his childhood and its influence on his poetry, and the conflict with his life as a critic and academic.

group.title: Australia Council archival film series: writers I

results.title: Kylie Tennant
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
Kylie Tennant drew her inspiration from people she knew, and her exuberant interview is in itself a valuable piece of Australian social history.
